questions.text: You are walking in a park when you notice an elderly person collapse in front of you. Which of the following is the first step in managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Check scene safety 

Explanation: 

  • Ensure scene safety: before starting any BLS, ensure the environment is safe. Remove the victim from any immediate danger, such as standing water or traffic.
  • Tap on the shoulder and speak loudly in a language the victim could understand to elicit a response from the victim.
  • Call for help, inform the emergency medical system, and get emergency equipment. 
  • Check for the carotid pulse for 5–10 seconds and the breathing effort simultaneously by looking for chest rise. 
    • Normal breathing with a definite carotid pulse: the victim needs to be assessed every 2 min or earlier to determine any change in condition.
    • Abnormal or no breathing with a definite carotid pulse: the victim is in respiratory arrest and should be provided normal tidal volume breaths every 5 s or 12 breaths every minute using mouth-to-mouth, mouth-to-mask, or bag-mask device ventilation.
    • Abnormal or no breathing without a definite carotid pulse: the victim is in cardiopulmonary arrest and requires high-quality CPR including cycles of compression and breaths at the earliest. (Option A)
  • A cycle of CPR is 30 chest compressions: 2 breaths with the speed of chest compressions at 120/min and compression depth at 5–6 cm.
  • Once the emergency equipment is available, like an AED or defibrillator, they are used for further resuscitation.

Automated External Defibrillator:

  • Turn On the AED.
  • Follow audio instructions: Listen to the voice prompts provided by the AED.
  • Attach pads: Place the AED pads on the victim’s chest while continuing chest compressions, one in the right infraclavicular region and 2nd below the left nipple into the axilla.
  • Analyze Heart Rhythm: allow the AED to assess the heart rhythm and ensure no one is touching the victim during this analysis.
  • Deliver Shock: if the AED indicates, administer the electric shock as directed.
  • Resume CPR: immediately continue CPR, starting with chest compressions.

questions.text: You are intern posted in ICU. Nurse calls you to assist for a sepsis patient whose ECG monitor is showing the following display and she has started chest compressions. Which of the following is the first step in managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is B: Defibrillation

  • ECG shows chaotic, irregular waveforms without distinct QRS complexes or P waves seen in ventricular fibrillation. This is a shockable rythm 
  • Immediate defibrillation is the primary treatment to restore a normal heart rhythm

questions.text: 65 year old patient with anterior wall MI develops asystole. Which of the following is the first step in managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- C: Chest compressions @30:2

Patient has developed Asystole/ Flat line ECG. First step would be to start CPR @30:2 to ensure blood flow to cerebral circulation. Epinephrine should be given as soon as possible. It may not be avaliable immediately and securing IV line will also take time.

questions.text:
Assertion: Cardioversion is the preferred treatment for hemodynamic compromise caused by  supraventricular tachycardia 
Reason: Synchronized direct current (DC) shock is administered at the peak of the R wave to avoid R on T phenomenon

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is a correct explanation of the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not a correct explanation of the assertion.
The assertion is true, but the reason is false.
The assertion is false, but the reason is true.

questions.solution:
Option A is correct 

The R-on-T phenomenon refers to a shock falling on the T wave (ventricular repolarization), which can induce ventricular fibrillation.

Synchronized cardioversion times the shock with the R wave, avoiding this risk. 

 

Feature

Cardioversion

Defibrillation
Definition

A synchronized electrical shock to reset the abnormal heart rhythm.

 

An unsynchronized shock to correct life-threatening arrhythmias.

Mechanism

Synchronized with the R wave in the ECG (delivered at the peak of the R wave)

Delivered irrespective of the R wave (unsynchronized)

Physiological Effect

Stops abnormal contractions to allow the heart to reset, followed by the SA node resuming normal activity

Halts all electrical activity in the heart, hoping normal rhythm restarts

Indications

Performed in arrhythmias where the heart is still contracting but irregularly, such as: 

  • Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)
  • Atrial Fibrillation (AF)
  • Atrial Flutter

Performed in life-threatening arrhythmias where the heart is not pumping blood effectively, such as:

  • Ventricular Fibrillation (VF)
  • Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia (VT)

Energy Level

Usually lower energy levels (e.g., 50-100 joules for AF)

Usually higher energy levels (e.g., 150-360 joules for VF)

Performed in

Elective procedure, typically not in emergencies.

Emergencies (like during a cardiac arrest).

Complications

Less risk of inducing dangerous arrhythmias due to synchronization.

Higher risk of inducing other arrhythmias (e.g., R-on-T phenomenon) if the shock is delivered improperly.

questions.text: You are resuscitating a patient with following ECG tracing in ER. CPR is given @30:2 and 10 ml of 1: 10,000 adrenaline is given twice at interval of 3 minutes but the tracing is still the same. What is next best step in managment of this patient
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Repeat 10 ml of 1: 10,000 adrenaline

Repeated adrenaline administration in asytole may convert this flat line ECG into ventricular fibrillation which can  then be given defibrillation to restore normal sinus rythm.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male in the ICU is having crashing blood pressure. ECG tracing shows Ventricular fibrillation. 200 J biphasic shock is given to patient. Which of the following is next best step for managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Start CPR  

Immediately after defibrillation, the rythm make some time to reset to normal. During this time, chest compressions must continue@30:2.

questions.text: An alcoholic is admitted with diagnosis acute pancreatitis. On day 2 evening, he is shifted to ICU for Ventilator assistance for ARDS. Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Set tidal volume of 12 mL/kg lean body weight
Set FiO2 at 1.0 and then titrate down to maintain pO2 55- 80 mm Hg
Adjust Respiratory rate to keep pH > 7.3

questions.solution:
Correct answer is: A: Set tidal volume of 12 mL/kg lean body weight

Tidal volume should be kept at 6 ml per kg of lean body weight to enable. FiO2 (Fraction of Inspired Oxygen) is Initially set at 1.0 (100% oxygen) and then reduced to the lowest level needed to maintain adequate oxygenation. Permissive hypercapnia is allowed so keeping a pH of >7.3 is fine while adjusting respiratory rate. 

Ventilator Settings for ARDS 

Parameter  Recommended Setting 
Mode  Volume Assist-Control (AC) or Pressure-Control Ventilation
Tidal Volume (VT) 4-6 mL/kg of predicted body weight (PBW) - Prevents barotrauma/volutrauma 
Plateau Pressure  ≤ 30 cm H2O - to reduce lung injury 
PEEP use PEEP -FiO2 titration table (typically 5 -15 cm H2O, can go up to 20 in severe ARDS)
FiO2 Strat with 100% (1.0), then titrate down to maintain SpO2 88-95% or PaO2 55-80 mmHg
Respiratory Rate Adjust to maintain pH ≥ 7.30 (can be up to 35/min); permissive hypercapnia is allowed 
Driving Rate  Keep <15 cm H2O - (Driving pressure = Plateau pressure - PEEP)
I:E Ratio Typically 1:1 to 1:2 (can prolong expiration if needed)
Prone Positioning  Consider if PaO2/FiO2 < 150 despite optimal settings

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the hospital and placed on mechanical ventilation. His arterial blood gas analysis shows the following values: PaO2: 86 mmHg, PaCO2: 50 mmHg and pH: 7.32. Which of the following management strategies should be prioritized for this patient?

choices.text: Decrease the tidal volume to improve ventilation.
Increase the FiO2 immediately to avoid oxygen toxicity.
Increase PEEP to improve oxygenation and maintain lung recruitment.
Increase the expiratory time to promote CO2 washout

questions.solution:
Answer is D: Increase the expiratory time to promote CO2 washout

In a mechanically ventilated COPD patient, the most appropriate strategy is to increase expiratory time to enhance CO₂ washout and prevent air trapping. These patients have prolonged airway resistance, and allowing insufficient expiratory time can lead to dynamic hyperinflation and auto-PEEP, worsening ventilation.

Decreasing tidal volume (Option A) would reduce minute ventilation and worsen hypercapnia. Increasing FiO₂ (Option B) is unnecessary as the patient’s PaO₂ is adequate, and excessive oxygen may depress respiratory drive in COPD. While increasing PEEP (Option C) may help alveolar recruitment in restrictive lung diseases, it must be used cautiously in COPD due to the risk of worsening air trapping. Therefore, optimizing expiratory time by reducing respiratory rate and adjusting the I:E ratio is the safest and most effective intervention in this scenario.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with Guillain-Barré Syndrome develops progressive respiratory muscle weakness and is placed on mechanical ventilation. Which of the following ventilator modes is most appropriate in this setting?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Assist-Control Mechanical Ventilation

Assist-Control (ACMV) provides full ventilatory support, delivering breaths whether initiated by the patient or not — ideal for neuromuscular weakness like GBS.
PSV (option A)  requires some spontaneous respiratory effort, which GBS patients may lack.
SIMV (option B) allows spontaneous breathing between mandatory breaths but may lead to fatigue in GBS.
CPAP (option D) is a non-invasive mode suited for spontaneous breathing and not indicated for ventilatory failure from neuromuscular paralysis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male is on mechanical ventilation for acute hypoxemic respiratory failure (Type 1). His latest ABG shows:
pH: 7.43, PaCO₂: 38 mmHg, PaO₂: 54 mmHg, HCO₃⁻: 24 mEq/L.
Which of the following changes should be made to improve his oxygenation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Increase Fio2

The patient has Type 1 respiratory failure (low PaO₂ with normal PaCO₂), indicating a pure oxygenation problem.
Increasing FiO₂ is the most direct and effective way to raise PaO₂.It is alos the lastest and simplest way to improve oxygenation. It provides immediate increase in alveolar oxygen concentration and thus raises PaO₂ quickly. Always titrate FiO₂ up to 60% (0.6) before increasing PEEP.
Increasing tidal volume (A) or minute ventilation (D) would reduce CO₂, not help oxygenation.
Decreasing RR (C) would worsen oxygenation by lowering minute ventilation and overall alveolar exposure to oxygen.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is admitted to the ICU after sustaining blunt chest trauma in a motor vehicle accident. Chest imaging reveals pulmonary contusions. After 48 hours, he develops severe hypoxemia with PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio of 110, bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, and no signs of left heart failure. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Insert a wide-bore needle in the fifth intercostal space
Start intravenous furosemide to reduce pulmonary edema
Begin low tidal volume mechanical ventilation
Initiate high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Low volume ventilation 

This patient has developed ARDS, likely secondary to pulmonary contusion, confirmed by bilateral infiltrates and low PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio. The cornerstone of ARDS management is lung-protective ventilation using low tidal volumes (4–6 mL/kg of predicted body weight) to prevent volutrauma and barotrauma. Option A (wide-bore needle) is used for tension pneumothorax, which would present with absent breath sounds and hemodynamic compromise, not diffuse infiltrates. Option B (Lasix) may be harmful here, as ARDS is due to inflammatory alveolar damage, not fluid overload. Option D (HFNC) is insufficient in moderate-to-severe ARDS, where invasive ventilation is required to maintain oxygenation and protect lungs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with acute shortness of breath, orthopnea, and bilateral pulmonary crackles. Work up shows elevated Pro-NT- BNP levels and ABG shows type 1 respiratory failure with pO2=60 mm Hg. Which of the following is best to improve his oxygenation status?
questions.solution:
Answer is D: NIV using Bi-PAP

  • The patient has acute decompensated heart failure (orthopnea, crackles, elevated NT-proBNP) with Type 1 respiratory failure (hypoxemia without hypercapnia).

  • BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure) helps by:

    • Providing positive pressure during inspiration (IPAP) and expiration (EPAP), improving oxygenation and offloading the failing left ventricle.

    • Reducing preload and afterload, thus relieving pulmonary edema and improving gas exchange.

  • HFNC improves oxygenation but lacks the positive pressure support needed in pulmonary edema.

  • Invasive ventilation is reserved for severe respiratory distress, altered mental status, or failure of NIV.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of COPD presents with increasing dyspnea, productive cough, and confusion. Arterial blood gas (ABG) shows pH 7.30, pCO₂ 58 mmHg, and pO₂ 55 mmHg. He is hemodynamically stable. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation

This patient with COPD exacerbation shows moderate hypercarbia (pH 7.30, pCO₂ 58 mmHg) and respiratory acidosis, which is an indication of NIV. NIV, such as BiPAP, can reduce the work of breathing, improve gas exchange, and prevent the need for intubation. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable and able to protect his airway, NIV is the appropriate next step.

 

Noninvasive Positive-Pressure Ventilation (NIV)

NIV refers to positive-pressure ventilation delivered through a nasal or full-face mask, either at a continuous pressure (CPAP) or with varying inspiratory and expiratory pressures (BiPAP).

Modes:
Modern noninvasive ventilators can provide full support, including volume control ventilation.

Indications
  • Acute respiratory failure: This treatment is effective for conditions that respond quickly to treatment, reducing the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
  • COPD exacerbations: NIV benefits moderate hypercarbia (pH 7.25-7.35), reducing the need for intubation and hospital stay. Severe respiratory acidosis (pH < 7.2) may require mechanical ventilation with intubation. (Option B)
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary oedema: Acts as adjunctive therapy, improving gas exchange and respiratory mechanics alongside diuresis and vasodilators.
  • Chronic respiratory failure: This is useful in restrictive lung diseases (e.g., severe scoliosis, respiratory muscle weakness) and chronic hypercapnia in COPD, reducing hospital admissions when used nocturnally.

Advantages

  • Reduces work of breathing
  • Improves pulmonary compliance
  • Recruits collapsed (atelectatic) alveoli
  • Requires less sedation compared to invasive ventilation
  • Shortens hospital stay
  • Lowers intubation rates without the risks of endotracheal intubation

Contraindications
  • Inability to protect the airway (e.g., severe encephalopathy)
  • High aspiration risk (e.g., vomiting, upper GI bleeding)
  • Difficulty clearing respiratory secretions
  • Facial trauma/surgery
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • Significant hemodynamic instability

 

Immediate endotracheal intubation (Option A): Reserved for severe respiratory acidosis (pH < 7.2) or failed NIV. This patient’s pH is 7.30, indicating moderate acidosis.

 

Intravenous antibiotics only (Option C): While antibiotics may be needed, they do not address acute respiratory failure or hypercarbia.

 

High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (Option D): Helps with oxygenation but does not manage hypercapnia or improve ventilation as NIV does in COPD exacerbations.
